case_name: Commissioner of Sales Tax, Uttar Pradesh v. Dealer

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 2088 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2088 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 3, 1969 of the Allahabad High Court in S. Y. R. No. 306 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated April 3, 1969 of the Allahabad High Court in S. Y. R. No. 306 of 1967. C. Manchanda and O. P. Rana for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant is the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Uttar Pradesh is by special leave and is directed against the judgment of the Allahabad High Court

facts.text: Respondent is the dealer who carries on the business of selling food colours and syrup essences.

anchor.surface_text: answering the following question in the negative in favour of the respondent  hereinafter called the dealer  and against the Commissioner of Sales Tax, appellant Whether the food companyors

facts.text: The dealer carries on the business, inter alia, of selling food colours and syrup essences.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer carries on the business, inter alia, of selling food companyors and syrup essences. The dealer also carries on the business of petroleum jelly but we are number companycerned

facts.text: For the assessment year 1960-61, the Sales Tax Officer taxed food colours and syrup essences imported by the dealer from outside Uttar Pradesh under s. 3A treating them as imported colours and perfumes.

anchor.surface_text: For the said year the Sales Tax Officer taxed food companyors and syrup essences imported by the dealer from outside Uttar Pradesh under s. 3A of U.P. Sales Tax Act, 15 of 1948  hereinafter called the Act  treating them as imported companyors and perfumes.

facts.text: The figures of the dealer's trading account were accepted by the Sales Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The figures of the dealers trading account were accepted by the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: The dealer appealed against the order of the Sales Tax Officer to the Assistant Commissioner (Judicial) II Sales Tax, Kanpur and the appeal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer, according to whom, food companyors and syrup essences being unclassified goods were taxable under s. 3 and number under s. 3A of the Act, unsuccessfully appealed against the order of the Sales Tax Officer to the Assistant Commissioner  Judicial  II Sales Tax, Kanpur.

facts.text: Further revision by the dealer to the Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax, Lucknow failed.

anchor.surface_text: Further revision to the Court of the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax, Lucknow also failed.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1957-58, the Appellate Authority held food colours and essences of syrup to be unclassified items and granted relief to the dealer.

anchor.surface_text: It may, however, be pointed out that for the assessment year 1957-58 the Appellate Authority had, in disagreement with the assessing officer, held food companyors and essences of syrup to be unclassified items and had granted the relief claimed by the dealer.

facts.text: Department's revision for 1957-58 and dealer's revision for 1960-61 were heard together and disposed by common order dated November 19, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Against that decision of the Appellate Authority the Department preferred a revision to the Court of the Judge  Revision , Sales Tax. Both these revisions, by the Department with respect to the assessment year 1957- 58 and by the dealer with respect to the assessment year 1960-61 were heard together and disposed of by the companymon order dated November 19, 1965.

facts.text: Dealer's application for reference was allowed and the question was referred to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The dealers application for reference was, however, allowed and the learned Judge  Revisions . Sales Tax referred for determination of the Allahabad High Court he question reproduced in the beginning of this Judgment.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held food colours and syrup essences not to fall within items 10 and 37 of the Notification under s. 3A and answered the reference in the negative against the Department.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the dealers companytention and held food companyors and syrup essences number to fall within the entries at items number. 10 and 37 of the Notification under S. 3A of the Act. The reference was accordingly answered in the negative and against the Department.

facts.text: There is no dispute about the turnover.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute about the turnover.

facts.text: The dealer claims tax at 2 nP. per rupee on imported food colours and syrup essences as unclassified goods under s. 3.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer claims that on imported food companyors and syrup essences the rate of tax should be 2 nP. per rupee as unclassified goods under S. 3, whereas according to the Commissioner

facts.text: Commissioner claims tax at 6 nP. per rupee under s. 3A on imported food colours and syrup essences.

anchor.surface_text: the tax should be 6 nP. per rupee under s. 3A of the Act.

facts.text: Notification No. ST-905/X dated March 31, 1956 declares single point taxation for goods including items 10 Dyes and colours and compositions thereof and 37 Scents and perfumes.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers single point taxation by notification specifying point of levy and rate for specified goods; overrides s.3; inserted by U.P. Act 25 of 1948

concepts.unlisted_description: Single point taxation of specified goods

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 provides for liability to tax under the Act whereas section 3A, which was inserted by U.P. Act 25 of 1948 and has thereafter been amended from time to time, deals with single point taxation. Section 3A reads 3-A. Single point taxation (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in Section 3, the State Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, declare that the turnover in respect of any goods or class of goods shall not be liable to tax except at such single point in the series of sales by successive dealers as the State Government may specify.

concepts.interpretation: Full text quoted; allows declaration of single point levy at specified rate not exceeding 10 naya paise; notifications laid before assembly

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1955 the Governor of Uttar Pradesh issued a notification in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 3A of the Act. That notification so far as relevant for our purpose reads Notification No. ST-905/X dated 31st March, 1955. In exercise of the powers conferred by section 3A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 as amended from time to time and in supersession of all previous Notifications on the subject, the Governor of Uttar Pradesh is hereby pleased to declare that the turnover in respect of the goods, specified in the List below shall not with effect from April 1, 1956, be liable to tax except- (a) in the case of goods imported from outside Uttar Pradesh at the, point of sale by the importer and (b) in the case of goods manufactured in Uttar Pradesh at the point of sale by the manufacturer and the Governor is further pleased to declare that such turnover shall with effect from the said date be taxed at the rate of one anna per rupee. LIST Dyes and colours and compositions thereof. Scents and perfumes.

concepts.interpretation: Declares single point tax on listed goods including item 10 'Dyes and colours and compositions thereof' and item 37 'Scents and perfumes' at importer's sale point for imported goods

anchor.surface_text: The words- dyes and colours used in entry number 10 and the words scents and perfumes used in entry number 37 have to be construed in their own context and in the sense, as ordinarily understood and attributed to these words by people usually conversant with and dealing in such goods. Similarly the words food colours and syrup essences which are descriptive of the class of goods the sales of which are to be taxed under the Act have to be construed in the sense, in which they are popularly understood by those who deal in them and who purchase and use them.

concepts.interpretation: Words in sales tax entries/notifications to be construed in popular/commercial sense by dealers and consumers, not dictionary/technical meanings; applied to hold food colours not 'dyes and colours', essences not 'scents and perfumes'

anchor.surface_text: The narrow point requiring decision is whether good companyors and syrup essences imported by the dealer from outside U.P. fall within the entries 10 and 37 respectively. If they do, then the appeal of the Department has to succeed

arguments.claim: Food colours do not fall under item 10 'Dyes and colours...' as they are edible, while entry relates to non-food colouring/dyeing material for fabrics; essences not scents/perfumes as they flavor food, not appeal to smell.

anchor.surface_text: This is how the High Court has dealt with the point in controversy-- The notification with which we are concerned in the instant case is notification No. ST- 905/X dated March 31, 1956. Item No. 10 and 37 of that notification read as follows Dyes and colours and composition thereof.

arguments.claim: Words 'dyes and colours' in item 10 and 'scents and perfumes' in item 37 are unqualified and by plain general meaning cover food colours and syrup essences.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Manchanda, learned counsel for the appellant, assailed the reasoning and approach of the High Court. According to him the words dyes and colours in entry number 10 of the List in the Notification in question and the words scents and perfumes in entry number 37 of the said List are unqualified and there being no limitation discernible on their plain and general meaning, they must be held to be wide enough to cover food colours and syrup essences.

arguments.court_reasoning: Dictionary not safe guide; construe in popular commercial sense by dealers/users.

arguments.claim: Dictionaries, encyclopedias support broad meaning of colour, dye, essence, perfume covering food colours/essences.

arguments.court_reasoning: Dictionary gives shades of meaning, delusive guide; not helpful for sales tax entries.

arguments.claim: Perfume in item 37 includes dhoop/dhoop batti per precedent Indian Herbs Research.

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance was placed on the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Sales Tax U.P. v. Indian Herbs Research Supply Co. in which the word perfume was held to include dhoop and dhoop batti. The word perfume, it may be recalled occurs in the entry number 37 of the List in the Notification in question.

arguments.claim: Words in sales tax entries/notifications construed in popular/commercial sense by dealers and users, not technical/dictionary meanings.

anchor.surface_text: The words- dyes and colours used in entry number 10 and the words scents and perfumes used in entry number 37 have to be construed in their own context and in the sense, as ordinarily understood and attributed to these words by people usually conversant with and dealing in such goods.

arguments.claim: Precedents support popular meaning: e.g., artificial silk includes terylene etc., tooth powder toilet requisite, betel leaves vegetable, coal includes charcoal, powerloom cloth not mill cloth.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents learned counsel has in support of this view referred us to some decided cases. In Kishan Chand Chellaram v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer...

arguments.claim: Notification list scheme specifies edibles separately (e.g., salt, sugar, banaspati); items 10/37 not intended for edibles like food colours/essences.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be gainsaid that food colours and syrup essences are edible goods whereas dyes and colours and compositions thereof and scents and perfumes as specified in entries No. 10 and 37 of the List do not seem prima facie to connote that they are edible goods.

arguments.claim: PFA Rule 23 uses 'colouring matter' for food, suggesting 'colour' in item 10 broad enough for food colours.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not impressed; rule goes against submission.

arguments.claim: High Court view not grossly erroneous warranting interference under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: In any event assuming that another view as to the meaning of these entries is possible we have not been persuaded to hold that the view taken by the High Court is so grossly erroneous that we should interfere on special leave appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Goods under s.3A notification are luxury goods; food colours/essences used by richer class, presumed included.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants learned counsel had at one stage suggested that the goods intended to be taxed under s. 3A of the Act are all luxury goods and therefore food colours and syrup essences which are normally used by comparatively richer class of society should be presumed to have been intended to be included in items No. 10 and 37 of the List.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ntended to take within their fold goods popularly

arguments.court_reasoning: On closer scrutiny, point not developed.

holdings.text: Food colours and syrup essences imported by the dealer from outside U.P. do not fall within the entries 10 'Dyes and colours and compositions thereof' and 37 'Scents and perfumes' of Notification No. ST-905/X dated 31st March, 1955 under s. 3A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The narrow point requiring decision is whether good companyors and syrup essences imported by the dealer from outside U.P. fall within the entries 10 and 37 respectively. If they do, then the appeal of the Department has to succeed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entries construed in popular commercial sense by dealers and consumers; connote non-edible items for colouring/dyeing fabrics and perfumery appealing to smell; list scheme specifies edibles separately.

holdings.text: Food colours and syrup essences are not liable to tax under s. 3A but under s. 3 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act as unclassified goods.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the food companyor and essence are under the circumstances items to be taxed under section 3A within the numberification No. ST- 905/X dated March 31, 1956 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Do not fall within specified notification entries; s. 3A applies only to notified goods at single point; otherwise general levy under s. 3.

holdings.text: Words and expressions in sales tax notifications and entries are to be construed in the popular and commercial sense as understood by dealers and consumers dealing in such goods, not in technical or dictionary meanings.

anchor.surface_text: The words- dyes and colours used in entry number 10 and the words scents and perfumes used in entry number 37 have to be construed in their own context and in the sense, as ordinarily understood and attributed to these words by people usually conversant with and dealing in such goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by precedents like Sarin Chemical, Ramavatar, Jaswant Singh; dictionary meanings delusive; applied to distinguish edible food colours/essences from non-edible dyes/colours/scents/perfumes.

holdings.text: The scheme of the notification list indicates that entries 10 and 37 are not intended to include edible goods like food colours and syrup essences.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be gain said that food companyors and syrup essences are edible goods whereas dyes and companyors and companypositions thereof and scents and perfumes as specified in entries number. 10 and 3 7 of the List do number seem prima facie to companynote that they are edible goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Edibles like salt, sugar, banaspati specified separately; non-edibles distinguished; intention clear where both categories possible.

holdings.text: The view taken by the High Court is not so grossly erroneous as to warrant interference by the Supreme Court in special leave appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In any event assuming that another view as to the meaning of these entries is possible we have number been persuaded to hold that the view taken by the High Court is so grossly erroneous that we should interfere on special leave appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reasoning logical and rational; even if another view possible, not grossly erroneous.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons foregoing this appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For reasons above on interpretation and application to facts.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Sales Tax U.P. v. Indian Herbs Research Supply Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance was placed on the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Sales Tax U.P. v. Indian Herbs Research Supply Co. 1  in which the word perfume was held to include dhoop and dhoop batti. The word perfume, it may be recalled occurs in the entry number 37 of the List in the Notification in question. In our opinion the Random House Dictionary cannot serve as a safe guide in companystruing the words used in the List in the Notification in question for the purpose of deciding whether or number the words used in entries number. 10 and 37 companyer food companyors and syrup essences indeed this Dictionary is apt to be a somewhat delusive guide in understanding the meanings of the words and expressions with which we are companycerned in the companytext in which they are used.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Sales Tax, UP v. Indian Herbs Research Supply Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: the word perfume includes dhoop and dhoop batti
precedents.cited_holding: word perfume was held to include dhoop and dhoop batti

precedents.citation: Kishan Chand Chellaram v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer, Chintradripet 2

anchor.surface_text: In Kishan Chand Chellaram v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer, Chintradripet 2  a Bench of the Madras High Court held that Terylene, Terene, Decorn, Nylon, Nylex etc., came within the expression artificial silk occurring at item number 4 in the Third Schedule to the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959. In the companyrse of the judgment in  1   1970  25 S.T.C. 151.  2   1968  21 S.T.C. 367. that case it was observed that the import and companytent of those words have number been defined in the Sales Tax Acts and the Courts are bound to have recourse to the meaning attributable to such words by persons who are dealing in and utilising such goods.

precedents.case_name: Kishan Chand Chellaram v. Joint Commercial Tax Officer, Chintradripet
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of words like artificial silk as understood by persons dealing in and utilising such goods, not scientific meaning
precedents.cited_holding: Terylene, Terene, Decorn, Nylon, Nylex etc., came within the expression artificial silk

precedents.citation: Sarin Chemical Laboratory v. Commissioner of Sales Tax 1

anchor.surface_text: In Sarin Chemical Laboratory v. Commissioner of Sales Tax 1  this Court held tooth powder to be a toilet requisite and liable to sales tax at a single point under s. 3A of the Act read with entry number 6 of the numberification, with which we, are also companycerned in the present case, it being observed that the names of the, articles, sales and. purchases of which are liable to be taxed, given in a statute, unless defined in the statute, must be companystrued number in a technical sense but as understood in companymon par lance.

precedents.case_name: Sarin Chemical Laboratory v. Commissioner of Sales Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: names of articles in sales tax statutes to be construed in common parlance, not technical sense
precedents.cited_holding: tooth powder to be a toilet requisite

precedents.citation: Ramvatar Budhiprasad v. Assistant Sales Tax Officer Okola 2

anchor.surface_text: In this decision reference was made to an earlier decision of this Court by five Judges in Ramvatar Budhiprasad v. Assistant Sales Tax Officer Okola  2 in which betel leaves were number companysidered as vegetable.

precedents.case_name: Ramavtar Budhiprasad v. Assistant Sales Tax Officer, Akola
precedents.cited_holding: betel leaves were not considered as vegetable

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Sales Tax, P. Indore v. Jaswant Singh Charan Singh 3

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Sales Tax, P. Indore v. Jaswant Singh Charan Singh 3  the word companyl was held by this Court to include charcoal, it being observed that, while interpreting items in statutes like the Sales Tax Acts, resort should be had number to the scientific Or technical meaning of such terms, but to their popular meaning or the meaning attached to them by those dealing in them, that is to say, to their companymercial sense.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Pradesh, Indore v. Jaswant Singh Charan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: words like coal to be interpreted in popular or commercial sense by dealers and consumers, includes charcoal

precedents.citation: Sales Tax Commissioner U.P. v. Ladha Singh Mal Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: In Sales Tax Commissioner U.P. v. Ladha Singh Mal Singh 1  cloth manufactured by means of power-looms was held by this Court number to fall within the words cloth manufactured by mills in the Notification dated June 8, 1948, issued under s. 3A of the Act and the sale of such cloth was held number liable to be taxed at the higher rate of 6 ps. in a rupee. According to this decision power-loom cloth in popular language is never associated with mill cloth.

precedents.case_name: Sales Tax Commissioner, UP v. Ladha Singh Mal Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: power-loom cloth not within mill-made cloth based on popular language
precedents.cited_holding: cloth manufactured by power-looms not fall within cloth manufactured by mills

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons foregoing this appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
